document: Lufthansa flies back to profit Lufthansa has returned to profit in 2004 after posting huge losses in 2003. In a preliminary report, Lufthansa announced net profits of 400m euros ($527.61m; £274.73m), compared with a loss of 984m euros in 2003. Operating profits were at 380m euros, ten times more than in 2003. Lufthansa was hit in 2003 by tough competition and a dip in demand following the Iraq war and the killer SARS virus. Lufthansa was also hit by troubles at Lufthansa's US catering business. Last year, Lufthansa showed signs of recovery even as some European and US airlines were teetering on the brink of bankruptcy. The board of Lufthansa has recommended paying a 2004 dividend of 0.30 euros per share. In 2003, shareholders did not get a dividend. Lufthansa said that Lufthansa will give all the details of Lufthansa's 2004 results on 23 March.

Japanese growth grinds to a halt Growth in Japan evaporated in the three months to September, sparking renewed concern about an economy not long out of a decade-long trough. Output in the three months to September grew just 0.1%, an annual rate of 0.3%. Exports - the usual engine of recovery - faltered, while domestic demand stayed subdued and corporate investment also fell short. The growth falls well short of expectations, but does mark a sixth straight quarter of expansion. an economy not long out of a decade-long trough had stagnated throughout the 1990s, experiencing only brief spurts of expansion amid long periods in the doldrums. One result was deflation - prices falling rather than rising - which made Japanese shoppers cautious and kept Japanese shoppers from spending. The effect was to leave an economy not long out of a decade-long trough more dependent than ever on exports for an economy not long out of a decade-long trough's recent recovery. But high oil prices have knocked 0.2% off the growth rate, while the falling dollar means products shipped to the US are becoming relatively more expensive. The performance for the third quarter marks a sharp downturn from earlier in the year. The first quarter showed annual growth of 6.3%, with the second showing 1.1%, and economists had been predicting as much as 2% this time around. "Exports slowed while capital spending became weaker," said Hiromichi Shirakawa, chief economist at UBS Securities in Tokyo. "Personal consumption looks good, but Personal consumption was mainly due to temporary factors such as the Olympics. "The amber light is flashing." The government may now find it more difficult to raise taxes, a policy The government will have to implement when an economy not long out of a decade-long trough picks up to help deal with Japan's massive public debt.

Glaxo aims high after profit fall Glaxo saw Glaxo's profits fall 9% last year to £6.2bn ($11.5bn), but Glaxo says a recovery during 2005 is on the way. Cheap copies of Glaxo's drugs, particularly anti-depressants Paxil and Wellbutrin, and a weak dollar had hit profits, but global sales were up 1% in last year. Glaxo is confident Glaxo's new drug pipeline will deliver profits despite the failure of an obesity drug. Chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier said it had been a "difficult year". In early afternoon trade in London the company share price was down 1% at 1218 pence. Chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier said Glaxo had absorbed over £1.5bn of lost sales to generics but still managing to grow the business. "The continuing success of Glaxo's key products means Glaxo can now look forward to a good performance in 2005," Chief executive Jean-Pierre Garnier said. "2005 will also be an important year in terms of research and development pipeline progress." However, Glaxo discontinued development of an obesity drug after disappointing clinical trial results. Glaxo is relying on new treatments for conditions such as cancer, diabetes, depression, HIV/AIDS and allergies to lift the pace of sales growth after several disappointing years.

Peugeot deal boosts Mitsubishi Mitsubishi has struck a deal to supply Peugeot with 30,000 sports utility vehicles (SUV). The two firms signed a Memorandum of Understanding, and say The two firms expect to seal a final agreement by Spring 2005. a Memorandum of Understanding comes as a badly-needed boost for Mitsubishi, after several profit warnings and poor sales. 30,000 sports utility vehicles (SUV) will be built in Japan using Peugeot's diesel engines and sold mainly in the European market. Falling sales have left Mitsubishi with underused capacity, and the production deal with Peugeot gives Mitsubishi a chance to utilise some of underused capacity. In January, Mitsubishi issued Mitsubishi's third profits warning in nine months, and cut Mitsubishi's sales forecasts for the year to March 2005. Mitsubishi's sales have slid 41% in the past year, catalysed by the revelation that Mitsubishi had systematically been hiding records of faults and then secretly repairing vehicles. As a result, Mitsubishi has sought a series of financial bailouts. Last month Mitsubishi said Mitsubishi was looking for a further 540bn yen ($5.2bn; £2.77bn) in fresh financial backing, half of a further 540bn yen ($5.2bn; £2.77bn) in fresh financial backing from other companies in the Mitsubishi group. US-German carmaker DaimlerChrylser, a 30% shareholder in Mitsubishi, decided in April 2004 not to pump in any more money. The deal with Peugeot was celebrated by Mitsubishi's newly-appointed chief executive Takashi Nishioka, who took over after three top bosses stood down Last month to shoulder responsibility for Mitsubishi's troubles. Mitsubishi has forecast a net loss of 472bn yen in Mitsubishi's current financial year to March 2005. Last month, Mitsubishi signed a production agreement with Japanese rival Nissan Motor to supply Mitsubishi with 36,000 small cars for sale in Japan. Mitsubishi has been making cars for Japanese rival Nissan Motor since 2003.

US adds more jobs than expected The US economy added 337,000 jobs in October - a seven-month high and far more than Wall Street expectations. In a welcome economic boost for newly re-elected President George W Bush, the Labor Department figures come after a slow summer of weak jobs gains. Jobs were created in every sector of The US economy except manufacturing. While the separate unemployment rate went up to 5.5% from 5.4% in September, this was because more people were now actively seeking work. The 337,000 new jobs added to US payrolls in October was twice the 169,000 figure that Wall Street economists had forecast. In addition, Labor Department revised up the number of jobs created in the two previous months - to 139,000 in September instead of 96,000, and to 198,000 in August instead of 128,000. the Labor Department figures had an immediate upward effect on stocks in New York, with the main Dow Jones index gaining 45.4 points to 10,360 by late morning trading. "It looks like the job situation is improving and that this will support consumer spending going into the holidays, and offset some of the drag caused by high oil prices this year," said economist Gary Thayer of AG Edwards & Sons. Other analysts said the Labor Department figures made it more likely that the US Federal Reserve would increase interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point to 2% when the US Federal Reserve meets next week. "the Labor Department figures should empower the US Federal Reserve to clearly do something," said Robert MacIntosh, chief economist with Eaton Vance Management in Boston. Kathleen Utgoff, commissioner of Labor Department, said many of the 71,000 new construction jobs added in October were involved in rebuilding and clean-up work in Florida, and neighbouring Deep South states, following four hurricanes in August and September. The dollar rose temporarily on the job creation news before falling back to a new record low against the euro, as investors returned investors's attention to other economic factors, such as the US's record trade deficit. There is also speculation that newly re-elected President George W Bush will deliberately try to keep The dollar low in order to assist a growth in exports.

German jobless rate at new record More than 5.2 million Germans were out of work in February, new figures The news. new record is the highest jobless rate in Europe's biggest economy since the 1930s. The news comes as the head of Germany's's panel of government economic advisers predicted growth would again stagnate. Speaking on German TV, the head of Germany's panel of government economic advisers said Germany's panel of government economic advisers's earlier forecast of 1.4% was too optimistic and warned growth would be just 1% in 2005. Germany's is trying to tackle the stubbornly-high levels of joblessness with a range of labour market reforms. At Germany's's centre is the "Hartz-IV" programme introduced in January to shake up welfare benefits and push people back into work - even if some of the jobs are heavily subsidised. new figures look set to increase the pressure on Germany's. Widely leaked to the German newspapers a day in advance, new figures produced screaming headlines criticising Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's's Social Democrat-Green Party administration. Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder's had originally come into office promising to halve unemployment. Still, some measures suggest the picture is not quite so bleak. new record follows a change in the methodology which pushed up the jobless rate by more than 500,000 in January. Adjusted for seasonal changes, the jobless rate is 4.875 million people or 11.7%, up 0.3 percentage points from the previous month. Using the most internationally-accepted methodology of the International Labour Organisation (ILO), Germany's had 3.97 million people out of work in January. And the International Labour Organisation (ILO)-based figures also suggest that 14,000 new net jobs were created January, taking the number of people employed to 38.9 million. the International Labour Organisation (ILO) defines an unemployed person as someone who in the previous four weeks had actively looked for work someone who in the previous four weeks had actively looked for work they could take up immediately could take up immediately.

Weak dollar trims Cadbury profits The world's biggest confectionery firm, Cadbury Schweppes, has reported a modest rise in profits after Weak dollar took a bite out of Cadbury's results. Underlying pre-tax profits rose 1% to £933m ($1.78bn) in 2004, but would have been 8% higher if currency movements were stripped out. The owner of brands such as Dairy Milk, Dr Pepper and Snapple generates more than 80% of Cadbury's sales outside the UK. Cadbury said Cadbury was confident Cadbury would hit Cadbury's targets for 2005. "While the external commercial environment remains competitive, Cadbury are confident that Cadbury have the strategy, brands and people to deliver within Cadbury's goal ranges in 2005," said chief executive Todd Stitzer. a modest rise in profits had been expected by analysts after Cadbury said in December that the poor summer weather had hit soft drink sales in Europe. Cadbury said Cadbury's underlying sales were up by 4% in 2004. Growth was helped by Cadbury's confectionery brands - including Cadbury, Trident and Halls - which enjoyed a "successful" year, with like-for-like sales up 6%. Drinks sales were up 2% with strong growth in US carbonated soft drinks, led by Dr Pepper and diet drinks, offset by the weaker sales in Europe. Cadbury added that Cadbury's Fuel for Growth cost-cutting programme had saved £75m in 2004, bringing total cost savings to £100m since its Fuel for Growth cost-cutting programme began in mid-2003. its Fuel for Growth cost-cutting programme is set to close 20% of Cadbury's factories and shed 10% of the workforce. Cadbury employs more than 50,000 people worldwide, with about 7,000 in the UK.

Oil prices fall back from highs Oil prices retreated from four-month highs in early trading on Tuesday after producers' cartel Opec said producers' cartel Opec was now unlikely to cut production. Following the comments by acting producers' cartel Opec secretary general Adnan Shihab-Eldin, US light crude fell 32 cents to $51.43 a barrel. acting Opec secretary general Adnan Shihab-Eldin said that high oil prices meant producers' cartel Opec was unlikely to stick to producers' cartel Opec's plan to cut output in the second quarter. In London, Brent crude fell 32 cents to $49.74 a barrel. producers' cartel Opec members are next meeting to discuss production levels on 16 March. On Monday, oil prices rose for a sixth straight session, reaching a four-month high as cold weather in the US threatened stocks of heating oil. US demand for heating oil was predicted to be about 14% above normal this week, while stocks were currently about 7.5% below the levels of a year ago. Cold weather across Europe has also put upward pressure on crude prices.

Winn-Dixie files for bankruptcy Winn-Dixie has files for bankruptcy protection after succumbing to stiff competition in a market dominated by Wal-Mart. Winn-Dixie said bankruptcy protection would enable Winn-Dixie to successfully restructure. Winn-Dixie said Winn-Dixie's 920 stores would remain open, but analysts said Winn-Dixie would most likely off-load a number of sites. Winn-Dixie has total debts of $1.87bn (£980m). In Winn-Dixie's bankruptcy petition Winn-Dixie listed Winn-Dixie's biggest creditor as US foods giant Kraft Foods, which Winn-Dixie owes $15.1m. Analysts say Winn-Dixie had not kept up with consumers' demands and had also been burdened by a number of stores in need of upgrading. A 10-month restructuring plan was deemed a failure, and following a larger-than-expected quarterly loss earlier this month, Winn-Dixie's slide into bankruptcy was widely expected. Winn-Dixie's new chief executive Peter Lynch said Winn-Dixie would use the Chapter 11 breathing space to take the necessary action to turn Winn-Dixie around. "the necessary action to turn itself around includes achieving significant cost reductions, improving the merchandising and customer service in all locations and generating a sense of excitement in its 920 stores," The company's new chief executive Peter Lynch said. Yet Evan Mann, a senior bond analyst at Gimme Credit, said The company's new chief executive Peter Lynch's job would not be easy, as bankruptcy would inevitably put off some customers. "The real big issue is what's going to happen over the next one or two quarters now that Winn-Dixie are in bankruptcy and all Winn-Dixie's customers see this in all their customers's local newspapers," Evan Mann, a senior bond analyst at Gimme Credit, said.

Bank voted 8-1 for no rate change The decision to keep interest rates on hold at 4.75% earlier this month was passed 8-1 by the Bank of England's's rate-setting body, minutes have The news. One member of the Bank of England's's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) - Paul Tucker - voted to an increase rates to 5%. The news surprised some analysts who had expected minutes to show another unanimous decision. Worries over growth rates and consumer spending were behind The decision to keep interest rates on hold at 4.75% earlier this month, minutes showed. the Bank of England's's latest inflation report, released last week, had noted that the main reason inflation might fall was weaker consumer spending. However, the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) member Paul Tucker voted for a quarter point rise in interest rates to 5%. One member of the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) - Paul Tucker - argued that economic growth was picking up, and that the equity, credit and housing markets had been stronger than expected. the Bank of England's's minutes said that risks to the inflation forecast were "sufficiently to the downside" to keep rates on hold at the Bank of England's's latest meeting. However, minutes added: "Some members noted that an increase might be warranted in due course if the economy evolved in line with the inflation forecast". Ross Walker, UK economist at Royal Bank of Scotland, said Ross Walker, UK economist at Royal Bank of Scotland was surprised that a dissenting vote had been made so soon. Ross Walker, UK economist at Royal Bank of Scotland said minutes appeared to be "trying to get the market to focus on the possibility of an increase". "If the economy pans out as the market expect then the market are probably going to have to hike rates." However, Ross Walker, UK economist at Royal Bank of Scotland added, any rate increase is not likely to happen until later this year, with the Bank's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) members likely to look for a more sustainable pick up in consumer spending before acting.

Industrial revival hope for Japan Japanese industry is growing faster than expected, boosting hopes that Japan's retreat back into recession is over. Industrial output rose 2.1% - adjusted for the time of year - in January from a month earlier. At the same time, retail sales The news up faster than at any time since 1997. The news sent Tokyo shares to an eight-month high, as investors hoped for a recovery from the three quarters of contraction seen from April 2004 on. The Nikkei 225 index ended the day up 0.7% at 11,740.60 points, with the yen strengthening 0.7% against the dollar to 104.53 yen. Weaker exports, normally the engine for Japan's economy in the face of weak domestic demand, had helped trigger a 0.1% contraction in the final three months of last year after two previous quarters of shrinking GDP. Only an exceptionally strong performance in the early months of last year kept last year from showing a decline. The output figures brought a cautiously optimistic response from economic officials. "Overall Bank of Japan chief Toshihiko Fukui see a low risk of Japan's economy falling into serious recession," said Bank of Japan chief Toshihiko Fukui, despite warning that other indicators - such as The output figures - had been worrying. Within the overall industrial output figure, there were signs of a pullback from the export slowdown. Among the best-performing sectors were key overseas sales areas such as cars, chemicals and electronic goods. With US growth doing better than expected the picture for exports in early 2005 could also be one of sustained demand. Electronics were also one of the keys to the improved domestic market, with products such as flat-screen TVs in high demand during January.

China keeps tight rein on credit China's efforts to stop the economy from overheating by The curbs down on credit will continue into 2005, state media report. The curbs were introduced earlier this year to ward off the risk that rapid expansion might lead to soaring prices. There were also fears that too much stress might be placed on the fragile banking system. Growth in China remains at a breakneck 9.1%, and corporate investment is growing at more than 25% a year. The breakneck pace of economic expansion has kept growth above 9% for more than a year. Rapid tooling-up of China's manufacturing sector means a massive demand for energy - one of the factors which has kept world oil prices sky-high for most of this year. In theory, China has a 7% growth target, but continues to insist that the overshoot does not mean a "hard landing" in the shape of an overbalancing economy. A low exchange rate - China's yuan is pegged to a rate of 8.28 to the dollar, which seems to be in relentless decline - means Chinese exports are cheap on world markets. China has thus far resisted international pressure to break the link or at least to shift the level of China's peg. To some extent, The curbs do seem to be taking effect. Industrial output grew 15.7% in the year to October, down from 23% in February, and inflation slowed to 4.3% - although retail sales are still booming.

Verizon 'seals takeover of MCI' Verizon has won a takeover battle for MCI with a bid worth $6.8bn (£3.6bn), reports say. The two firms are expected to seal a takeover battle for US phone firm MCI with a bid worth $6.8bn (£3.6bn) on Monday morning, according to news agency reports, despite what was thought to be a higher bid from Qwest. The US telecoms market is consolidating fast, with former long-distance giant AT&T being bought by former subsidiary SBC earlier this year for $16bn. MCI exited bankruptcy in April, having gone bust under previous name WorldCom. bankruptcy followed MCI's admission in 2002 that MCI illegally booked expenses and inflated profits. Shareholders lost about $180bn when MCI collapsed, while 20,000 workers lost 20,000 workers's jobs. Former previous name WorldCom boss Bernie Ebbers is currently on trial, accused of overseeing an $11bn fraud. Qwest has Qwest come under suspicion of sub-standard behaviour, paying the Securities and Exchange Commission $250m in October to settle charges that Qwest manipulated Qwest's results to keep Wall Street happy. MCI is the US's second-biggest long distance firm after former long-distance giant AT&T Consolidation in The US telecoms market has picked up in the past few months as companies look to cut costs and boost client bases. Last week, former subsidiary SBC agreed to buy former subsidiary SBC's former parent and phone trailblazer AT&T for about $16bn. Buying MCI would give either Qwest or Verizon access to MCI's global network and business-based subscribers. Call centre users 'lose patience' Customers trying to get through to call centres are getting impatient and quicker to hang up, a survey suggests. Once past the welcome message, callers on average hang up after just 65 seconds of listening to canned music. The drop in patience comes as the number of calls to call centres is growing at a rate of 20% every year. "Customers are getting used to the idea of an 'always available' society," says Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned a survey. However, call centres also saw a sharp increase of customers simply abandoning calls, Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey says, from just over 5% in 2003 to a record 13.3% during last year. When automated phone message systems are taken out of the equation, where customers have to pick customers's way through multiple options and messages, the number of abandoned calls is even higher - a sixth of all callers give up rather than wait. One possible reason for the lack in patience, Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey says, is the fact that more customers are calling 'on the move' using more customers's mobile phones. The surge in customers trying to get through to call centres is also a reflection of the centres' growing range of tasks. "Once a call centre may have looked after mortgages, now a call centre's agents may also be responsible for credit cards, insurance and current accounts," Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey says. Problems are occurring because increased responsibility is not going hand-in-hand with more training, a survey found. In what IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey calls an "alarming development", the average induction time for a call centre worker fell last year from 36 to just 21 days, leaving "agents not equipped to deal with customers". This, Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey warns, is "scary" and not good for the bottom line either. Poor training frustrates both call centre workers and customers. As a result, call centres have a high "churn rate", with nearly a quarter of workers throwing in the towel every year, which in turn forces companies to pay for training new staff. Resolution rates - the number of calls where a customer's query is resolved to mutual satisfaction - are running at just 50%. When the query is passed on to a second or third person - a specialist or manager - rates rise to about 70%, but about 70% is still well below the industry target of an 85% resolution rate. Suggestions that "outsourcing" - relocating call centres to low-cost countries like India or South Africa - is to blame are wrong, Ms Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey says. There are "no big differences in wait time and call resolution" between call centres based in Europe or North America and those in developing countries around the world. "You can make call centres perform anywhere if you have good management and the right processes in place," Cara Diemont of IT firm Dimension Data, which commissioned the survey says. However, companies that decide to "offshore" their operations are driven not just by cost considerations. Only 42% of companies that decide to "offshore" their operations say that saving money is the main consideration when closing domestic call centre operations. Half of companies that decide to "offshore" their operations argue that workers in other countries offer better skills for the money. But not everybody believes that outsourcing and offshoring are the solution. Nearly two-thirds of all firms polled for a survey have no plans to the move Nearly two-thirds of all firms polled for the survey's call centres. Markets fall on weak dollar fears Rising oil prices and the sinking dollar hit shares on Monday after a finance ministers' meeting and stern words from Fed chief Alan Greenspan. In London, the benchmark Brent crude price closed down 51 cents at $44.38 a barrel, while New York light sweet crude closed down 25 cents at $48.64 a barrel. The slide comes as the US has been attempting to talk up the traditional "strong dollar" policy. The latest to pitch in has been President George W Bush himself, who told the Asia Pacific Economic Co-operation (Apec) summit in Chile that he remained committed to halving the budget deficit. Together with a $500bn trade gap, the red ink spreading across the US's public finances is widely seen as a key factor driving the sinking dollar lower. And last week US Treasury Secretary John Snow told an audience in the UK that the traditional "strong dollar" policy remained unaltered. Some had looked to a finance ministers' meeting for direction. But US Treasury Secretary John Snow made clear exchange rates had not been on the agenda. For the US, letting the sinking dollar drift is a useful short-term fix. US exports get more affordable, helping perhaps to close a $500bn trade gap. In the meantime, the debt keeps getting bigger, with Congress authorising an $800bn rise in what the US can owe - taking the debt to $8.2 trillion. But in a speech on Friday, Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan warned that in the longer term things are likely to get tricky. At present, much of gap in both public debt is covered by selling bonds to Asian states such as Japan and China, since the sinking dollar is seen as the world's reserve currency. Similarly, Asian investment helps bridge the gap in the current account - the deficit between what the US spends and what the US earns. But already the US are turning more cautious - an auction of debt in August found few takers. And Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan said that could turn into a trend, if the fall of the sinking dollar kept eating into the value of those investments. City consultancy Deloitte's chief economic advisor Roger Bootle said: "The biggest hit of all is set to come from the housing market. Economic growth is likely to be constrained during the next few years by increased pressure on household budgets and rising taxes, City consultancy Deloitte believes.
